Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Nanocarbon Air Cathodes for High-Temperature Solid-State Li-O2 Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1604392 PI: Wu, Gang
Title: Engineering Nanocarbon Air Cathodes for High-Temperature Solid-State Li-O2 Batteries

The Li-air (O2) battery is a promising next-generation energy storage device with high energy density that is superior to any conventional electrochemical power source. Practical applications of such batteries are hindered by several challenges, e.g., low efficiency of catalysts, safety issues related to flammability of organic fluid electrolytes, and durability. Replacing the flammable organic fluid electrolytes currently used in the batteries with highly Li+ conductive, fire-resistant, and robust inorganic solid-state electrolytes is a critical milestone to address these issues. The successful incorporation of solid-state electrolytes into battery technologies requires an understanding of the associated Li+-O2 electrochemical reactions, i.e., the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and evolution reaction (OER) in solid-state air cathodes. The proposed plan will develop a novel nano-structured, carbon-metal nanoparticle composite for a lithium-oxygen battery with a solid state electrolyte that will improve the performance and safety of Li-air batteries, as well as contribute to the understanding of other related battery systems.

The project will focus on studying solid-state O2 electrocatalysis in a porous air cathode consisting of a new Li3OCl electrolyte and a nitrogen-doped nanocarbon ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst. The following tasks will be performed: (1) engineering of porous structures with well-defined three-phase interfaces (electrolyte, catalyst, and O2) in air cathodes, (2) elucidation of temperature-dependent O2 diffusion and Li+ transport mechanisms along with electrochemical reaction kinetics in solid-state cathodes via synergistic modeling and experimental characterization efforts, and (3) design of 3D nanoporous air cathode architectures that provide efficient mass and charge transports along with sufficient activity and stability for high-temperature Li-O2 electrochemical reactions. In addition to training graduate students, the PIs also plan to engage undergraduates and high-school students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrochemical energy technologies such as batteries and fuel cells provide an ideal medium to store and release electricity as needed via the oxidation or reduction of active species. In particular, metal-air batteries, including Li-, and Zn-air batteries, provides much-increased energy density compared to traditional Li-ion batteries. However, current changes for practical applications are the inefficient air cathodes and electrolytes. In this project, we focus on the design of efficient air cathodes containing highly active and stable carbon catalysts for oxygen reactions toward solid-state metal-air battery applications.

The primary outcomes of this project include experimental and theoretical advances in nanostructured carbon air electrodes concerning catalyst design, synthesis, and characterization, along with their assembly with solid-state electrolytes into metal-air batteries.

In particular, we invented a 3D mesoscale and high-surface area (1645 m2g–1) nitrogen-doped graphene composite carbon, the highest record surface area for air cathodes, derived from inexpensive heteroatom polymer (polyaniline-PANI) with controlled thermal treatment. The unique morphologies generated remarkably enhanced electrochemical properties. Also, we discovered Mn doping has a promotional role in stabilizing nanocarbon catalysts for corrosive electrolytes. The carbon composites comprise substantial carbon tube forests growing on a thick and dense graphitic substrate, demonstrating the encouraging oxygen reaction activity and stability. This work provides a strategy to stabilize carbon catalysts by appropriately integrating transition metals and engineering carbon structures. During the project, we developed a 3D printing technology to fabricate a porous electrode network for improved charge transfer and mass transport

Compared to traditional metal catalysts, new air electrodes containing atomically dispersed and nitrogen-coordinated single metal site (e.g., Fe, Co, Mn, or Ni) catalysts were developed, which hold great promise to replace platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts in electrochemical energy storages. This project focuses on emerging developments in mechanistic understanding, innovative synthetic concepts, and performance improvement of the newly emerged catalysts. We developed effective synthesis methods to enhance intrinsic catalyst activity and increase site density, starting from theoretical and computational analysis of active sites and reaction pathways. We newly introduced a strained concept for the M-N coordination of single metal sites. We experimentally and theoretically discovered that the strain is critical for catalyst activity and stability during the oxygen reaction, which thermal activation conditions can accurately control. Through accessing advanced user facilities at nationals labs, we developed different in-situ/operando spectroscopy characterization, aiming to elucidate structure-property correlations.  

To eventually address the stability issues of the promising single metal site catalyst, we developed a novel electrospinning approach to incorporating highly active single metal sites into the highly graphitized carbon network consisting of carbon fibers. The enhanced intrinsic activity is attributed to the extra graphitic N dopants surrounding the CoN4 moieties. The highly graphitized carbon matrix in the catalyst is beneficial for enhancing the carbon corrosion resistance, thereby promoting catalyst stability

Finally, we elucidate the structural evolution of CoN4 sites during thermal activation by developing a zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF)‐8‐derived carbon host as an ideal model for Co2+ ion adsorption. The critical transition occurs at 700 °C and becomes optimal at 900 °C, generating the highest intrinsic activity and four‐electron selectivity for the oxygen reaction in air cathodes. The general understanding of regulating metal‐nitrogen coordination structures through controlled thermal activation can universally tune intrinsic activity and selectivity of single metal sites catalysts, therefore benefiting other electrocatalysis processes in electrochemical energy technologies

The scientific knowledge obtained from the project has been documented in well-known peer-reviewed journal publications, including Chem. Rev., Chem. Soc. Rev, Nat. Cataly., J. Am. Chem. Soc., Angew. Chem.-Int. Edit., Adv. Mater., Energy Environ. Sci. etc., which are available for researchers for advancing new processes and technologies.

The new research outcomes have been incorporated into “Electrochemical Energy and Environmental Technologies”and “Materials Science and Engineering” courses. Multiple leveled students received training on electrochemistry, materials synthesis and characterization, battery technologies, and computational studies. Several female and African American graduate students received comprehensive training on electrochemistry and batteries. This project also helped build a battery laboratory currently used as an infrastructure for a project design course, “Chemical Engineering Lab” for junior undergraduate students in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering at the University at Buffalo, SUNY.

The successful project lays a solid foundation for developing high energy density, low cost, and safe electrochemical energy storage and conversion technologies for stationary and transportation applications. The fundamental understanding and prototype development achieved during this project could provide critical infrastructure to enable the scale-up and integration of advanced energy materials into practical devices for performance validation, demonstration, and commercialization by our industry in-kind collaborator. These outcomes will further generate broader impacts on developing a variety of energy storage materials and provide essential principles for clean energy technologies, including battery, fuel cell, water splitting, supercapacitors, and electrosynthesis, fast-expanding science, and engineering research frontiers.
